question: What reconciliation records have to go into the Resolution Pack for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, and how often must the Authorised Person do the reconciliations and counts involving Third Party Agents, Safe Custody Assets, and Client ledger balances?
gold_answer: The Resolution Pack for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments, because those reconciliation records are expressly part of the records that must be included in the Resolution Pack [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Separately, the Authorised Person must carry out specific reconciliation and verification activities on set cycles, and it should keep records showing it has done so: every calendar month it must reconcile its records of Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents to the monthly statements it receives from those Third Party Agents; at least every six months it must physically count all Safe Custody Assets held by the Authorised Person or its Nominee Company and reconcile that count to its own records; and at least every six months it must reconcile each Client’s ledger balance to the Authorised Person’s records of Safe Custody Assets balances held in Client Accounts [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6]. In practice, the Resolution Pack should therefore contain the latest reconciliation outputs so the Authorised Person can evidence compliance with both the inclusion requirement and the timing requirements.

(b)	at least every six months, count all Safe Custody Assets physically held by the Authorised Person, or its Nominee Company, and reconcile the result of that count to the records of the Authorised Person; and
(c)	at least every six months, reconcile individual Client ledger balances with the Authorised Person's records of Safe Custody Assets balances held in Client Accounts.

question: In the context where certain notification requirements applicable to Recognised Investment Exchanges are stated to apply to MTFs (using Virtual Assets), what must a Recognised Body notify the Regulator about when its Governing Body delegates Regulatory Functions to a standing committee, and how quickly must that notification be made?
gold_answer: When an MTF (using Virtual Assets) is brought within the scope of the notification regime described as applying to Recognised Investment Exchanges, those notification and information requirements operate as additional requirements for that MTF, alongside any other applicable notification requirements identified in the same guidance context [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]. Within that framework, a Recognised Body must notify the Regulator, in the circumstances noted, about governance arrangements involving standing committees where the Governing Body delegates any of its Regulatory Functions to a standing committee, or appoints a standing committee to manage or oversee the carrying out of any of the Recognised Body’s Regulatory Functions. The timing requirement for that notification is “as soon as practicable.” The information that must be provided with the notification is (a) the names of the members of that standing committee and (b) the terms of reference of that standing committee, including a description of any powers delegated to the committee and any conditions or limitations placed on the exercise of those powers [#TGT:4089ddbd-ee76-45ed-a673-48384237c975].

These are additional requirements applicable to MTFs using Virtual Assets. question: How should the Board of a Listed Entity reconcile its duty to ensure equality of treatment for holders of Securities of a particular class or type with a proposal to allot, issue or grant Shares with Weighted Voting Rights that alters equality and proportionality of Shareholder voting power and equity interest, and what approval condition applies?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity can proceed with Shares with Weighted Voting Rights only if it both (i) satisfies the specific approval condition for creating such rights and (ii) manages the resulting rights structure in a way that is consistent with the Board’s equality-of-treatment duty as it applies within each class or type of Securities. [#SRC:12f21edd-7868-4706-b1f4-3b2e9af8d6aa] The Board’s baseline obligation is to ensure equal treatment of all holders of Securities within the same class or type for all rights that attach to that class or type. [#TGT:194cf07e-3ce5-429a-9d01-6e1c25bef4ae] At the same time, the Listed Entity is expressly permitted, with the Regulator’s approval, to allot, issue or grant Shares with Weighted Voting Rights, which by design changes the equality and proportionality of Shareholder voting power and equity interest (as established in Rule 9.3.3). [#SRC:12f21edd-7868-4706-b1f4-3b2e9af8d6aa] In applying these together, the Board should treat the weighted voting feature as a rights attribute of the relevant Shares and then ensure that all holders of Securities of that particular class or type are treated equally in respect of the rights attaching to that class or type, while recognizing that the rules contemplate departures from equality and proportionality in voting power/equity interest when Weighted Voting Rights are issued with approval. [#TGT:194cf07e-3ce5-429a-9d01-6e1c25bef4ae] [#SRC:12f21edd-7868-4706-b1f4-3b2e9af8d6aa]
source_text: Weighted Voting Rights. A Listed Entity may, upon approval from the Regulator, allot, issue or grant Shares with Weighted Voting Rights, altering its Share capital in relation to the equality and proportionality of Shareholder voting power and equity interest (as established in Rule 9.3.3).

question: Before a PFP Operator publishes a financing proposal for a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, what due diligence must it perform to support its disclosure obligations, and for how long must it maintain records evidencing that due diligence and related communications and disclosures?
gold_answer: Before publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence on the PFP Prospect to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it, and that due diligence must include (at a minimum) reviewing information provided by the PFP Prospect covering: (i) management details and background, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers; (ii) the PFP Prospect’s background, including financial soundness, good standing and (where relevant) regulatory status; and (iii) the financing proposal itself to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, the content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. In addition, the PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep records of the due diligence it undertook, as well as all disclosures made in accordance with the applicable disclosure rules and all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7].

(a)	all disclosures made in accordance with Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2;
(b)	all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect; and
(c)	the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1.

Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and

question: When the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, and the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider agree in writing that the rule on liability for charges does not apply, what liability must the Payment Service Provider otherwise bear to its Payment Service User for charges and interest arising from a Payment Transaction that is not executed, is defectively executed, or is executed late?
gold_answer: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider are permitted to agree in writing that specified rules do not apply, including the rule addressing liability for charges [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. Absent (or outside the scope of) such a written agreement, the Payment Service Provider must meet the baseline liability described for execution failures: it is liable to its Payment Service User for any charges for which the Payment Service User is responsible and any interest which the Payment Service User must pay as a consequence of the non-execution, defective execution, or late execution of a Payment Transaction by the Payment Service Provider [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa]. In practical compliance terms, the written agreement functions as a permitted carve-out for the identified rule(s), but it does not change the fact that the obligation in the liability statement attaches when the Payment Service Provider’s non-execution, defective execution, or late execution causes the Payment Service User to incur charges or interest. The parties should therefore document clearly whether and how the carve-out is intended to affect allocation of such charges and interest.
target_text: A Payment Service Provider is liable to its Payment Service User for any charges for which the Payment Service User is responsible and any interest which the Payment Service User must pay as a consequence of the non-execution, defective or late execution of a Payment Transaction by the Payment Service Provider.

question: When a Payment Order for a single Payment Transaction is sent using a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, how should the Payment Service Provider determine which post‑initiation disclosures it must still provide immediately after initiation versus which general information it may omit because another Payment Service Provider has provided or will provide it under Section 19.2 for the Framework Contract?
gold_answer: For a Payment Order transmitted via a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider for that single Payment Transaction may omit only the “general information” that would otherwise be required under Rule 19.5.1, but only to the extent that such general information has been provided or will be provided under Section 19.2 by another Payment Service Provider in respect of the Framework Contract. [#SRC:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2] However, immediately after the initiation of the Payment Order, the Payment Service Provider must still provide or make available the specific post‑initiation items listed (to the Payer and, where applicable, the Payee), because these are the required immediate confirmations and transaction details rather than the general information covered by the Framework Contract disclosure. [#TGT:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] In practice, this means the provider should ensure delivery of: confirmation that initiation was successful with the Payer’s Payment Service Provider; a reference to identify the Payment Transaction (including Payer/Payee and any transferred information where appropriate); the transaction amount and currency; any charges and any applicable breakdown; any exchange rate used (or a reference) and the post‑conversion amount; the date the Payment Order was received; and the Credit Value Date. [#TGT:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] The omission is limited to the general information already handled under Section 19.2 for the Framework Contract by another Payment Service Provider, and does not displace these immediate post‑initiation disclosures. [#SRC:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]
source_text: Where a Payment Order for an individual Payment Transaction is transmitted by way of a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider in respect of that single Payment Transaction need not provide or make available under Rule 19.5.1 the general information which has been provided or will be provided under Section 19.2 by another Payment Service Provider in respect of a Framework Contract.

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that complied with the detailed content requirements for Production Targets, under what conditions may a later disclosure about the same Production Target omit the Rule 11.8.2 content items (including the required prominent cautionary statements for Inferred Mineral Resources and/or an Exploration Target), and what specific confirmations or cross-references must the later disclosure still include?
gold_answer: A subsequent disclosure about a Production Target can omit the detailed information otherwise required for a Rule 11.8.2 disclosure (such as the material assumptions, proportion breakdowns, and the specified prominent cautionary statements) only if it is framed as a follow-on to an earlier Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that already met those requirements. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] To rely on this streamlined approach, the later disclosure must (i) point back to the earlier disclosure and make clear that the earlier disclosure was compliant with the Rule 11.8.2 content requirements, and (ii) include an express confirmation that the material assumptions underpinning the original Production Target continue to apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] In addition, if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement corresponding to the required Inferred Mineral Resources warning. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] Likewise, if the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement corresponding to the required Exploration Target warning. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] These conditions operate against the baseline that a Rule 11.8.2 disclosure otherwise must include specified assumptions and other prescribed elements. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: For a Listed Entity/Reporting Entity that is required to provide annual reporting on its compliance with Corporate Governance Principles, what must the Listed Entity include in its annual financial report regarding adoption of the best practice standards, explanations for any non-adoption or partial adoption, and the Directors’ statement on the effectiveness of the Corporate Governance framework?
gold_answer: Listed Entities/Reporting Entities have an obligation to undertake annual reporting on their compliance with Corporate Governance Principles [#SRC:88ccc385-cfe8-4e4e-afd3-80026e74b4dd]. Where the annual financial report requirements apply, the Listed Entity must ensure that its annual financial report (i) states whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the Corporate Governance Principles) have been adopted, (ii) if those standards have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted, explains why full adoption did not occur and describes what actions, if any, have been taken to achieve compliance to the extent the relevant standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted, and (iii) includes a statement by Directors on whether, in their opinion, the Listed Entity’s Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, supported by information and any assumptions, and including qualifications if necessary [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. Together, these elements operationalize the annual compliance reporting obligation by requiring both a clear adoption status and a reasoned, action-oriented account of gaps, alongside a Directors’ effectiveness assessment.
source_text: Note that Listed Entities/Reporting Entities are also required to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of their compliance with Corporate Governance Principles.
