(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: In a Takeover or Merger where a Listed Entity seeks the Regulator’s prior written consent to release a holding lock on Restricted Securities, what written agreements and acceptance thresholds must be in place (including where the transaction is an offer versus a scheme), and how does this interact with the requirement to obtain and submit a holding-lock undertaking within two Business Days after issue?
gold_answer: To obtain the Regulator’s prior written consent to release a holding lock on Restricted Securities, the Listed Entity must align the release request with both the post-issue holding-lock undertaking framework and the specific consent preconditions for a Takeover or Merger. The holding lock is expected to be put in place through an undertaking obtained from an appropriate intermediary (for example, a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator considers suitable) and submitted to the Regulator within two Business Days after the Restricted Securities are issued; that undertaking must also commit not to release the lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] For consent in a Takeover or Merger, the Regulator will not consent unless the applicable transaction-structure conditions are met. If there is an offer, it must cover all Ordinary Securities (or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all Securities in the same class), and holders of at least half of the non-Restricted Securities to which the offer relates must have accepted. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing that the holding lock is immediately re-imposed for any Securities not acquired under the offer. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If conducted by scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity must agree in writing to immediate re-imposition if the Takeover does not take effect. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]
source_text:
Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator will not provide its consent under Rule 9.6.11 unless, to the extent to which they are applicable, all the following requirements are met:
(1)	where there is an offer for Securities:
(a)	the offer is for all of the Ordinary Securities or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all the Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities;
(b)	holders of at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities, to which the offer relates, have accepted; and
(c)	if the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder agree in writing that the holding lock (imposed under Rule 9.6.9) be immediately re-imposed for each Security that is not bought by the offeror under the offer; and
(2)	where the offer is to be conducted by way of a ‘scheme’, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity in which the Restricted Securities are held agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 be immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.
target_text: Timing and Enforcement. A Listed Entity must obtain, and submit to the Regulator, within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by it, and not to release the holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent.

question: During an investigation, when the Investigator seeks to obtain relevant information or documents on a compulsory basis, what written-notice directions may the Investigator impose on the Person Under Investigation or any other person, and how does this relate to the alternative of obtaining the same material voluntarily?
gold_answer: During an investigation, the Investigator is permitted to obtain relevant information and/or documents either compulsorily or voluntarily, so the compulsory route is an available option rather than the only mechanism for gathering material [#SRC:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4]. Where the Investigator proceeds on a compulsory basis, the TARGET text specifies that the Investigator may do so by issuing a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. That notice may require the recipient to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions, to produce specified documents (or documents of a specified description) at a specified time and place, and to provide information or assistance as the Investigator may require. It may also require the recipient to permit the Investigator to enter the recipient’s business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy documents on those premises. Read together, the SOURCE frames the overall permission to obtain relevant material compulsorily or voluntarily, while the TARGET details the concrete compulsory directions available via written notice.
source_text: Power to require documents or information . During an investigation, the Investigator may obtain relevant information and/or documents either on a compulsory basis, principally through the exercise of its powers under section 206(1)(b) and (c) of FSMR, or on a voluntary basis.

question: If the Regulator thinks a name is confusing or clashes with another name, what kinds of names can it step in on (Fund, Sub-Fund, or class of Units), and who can it tell to change the name?
gold_answer: When the Regulator believes a name is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with a name used by another Fund, Sub-Fund, or class of Units, it has the power to make a direction under Section 117 of FSMR. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] The set of names that can trigger this power includes the name of a Fund, a Sub-Fund, and also a class of Units in a Fund, so the Regulator’s concern is not limited to only the top-level Fund name. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] If the issue relates to the name of a Fund or a Sub Fund, the Regulator can require a specific fix by directing the Fund Manager to change that name. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] This means the decision point is the Regulator’s opinion about conflict, undesirability, or misleading character, and the operational obligation (for Fund/Sub Fund names) falls on the Fund Manager to implement the change when directed. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] Taken together, you should treat naming reviews as covering Fund/Sub-Fund/class-of-Units names, and be ready for a direction that specifically instructs the Fund Manager to rename a Fund or Sub Fund. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff]
source_text: Pursuant to Section 117 of FSMR, the Regulator has the power to make a direction if a name of a Fund, Sub-Fund or class of Units in a Fund is undesirable, misleading or conflicts with a name used by another Fund, Sub-Fund or class of Units of a Fund.
target_text:
Power to make a Direction
If, in the opinion of the Regulator, the name of a Fund or of a Sub Fund conflicts with the name of another Fund or Sub-Fund or is undesirable or misleading, it may direct the Fund Manager to change the name of the Fund or the Sub Fund.

question: If an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 falls below the required Capital Resources level compared with its Capital Requirement, what must it do to tell the Regulator, and does it also need to follow up in writing?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 finds that its Capital Resources have fallen below 120% of its Capital Requirement, it has an immediate duty to notify the Regulator as soon as that condition occurs [#SRC:c08e86ed-69f1-4d9f-81bf-af5206de7e41]. The obligation is not limited to a rapid initial alert: it must also confirm the notification in writing, so there is a required written follow-up (or written confirmation) to the Regulator after the immediate notice [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d]. In practical terms, the rule sets a clear trigger (Capital Resources below the 120% threshold), identifies exactly who it applies to (Authorised Persons in Categories 3B, 3C or 4), and requires two linked actions: immediate notification and written confirmation. Both steps are mandatory once the threshold is crossed, and both are directed to the Regulator.
source_text: An Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must notify the Regulator immediately if its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement, in accordance with Rule 3.20.2.
target_text: Notifications to the Regulator. An Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must notify the Regulator immediately and confirm in writing if its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement.

question: When is an Authorised Person put in Category 2, and how can you tell it is not Category 1 based on what its Financial Services Permission lets it do?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person falls into Category 2 when its Financial Services Permission allows it to do Providing Credit or to do Dealing in Investments as Principal (and not as Matched Principal), its dealing permission is not restricted to a limited scope of dealing, and it also does not meet the criteria for Categories 1 or 5 [#SRC:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f]. The Target text adds practical classification guidance: even if the firm can do other Regulated Activities, Category 2 is driven by being authorised for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and by not being authorised for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1; it also explains that if the firm’s dealing is limited to acting only as Matched Principal, that dealing sits in Category 3A rather than Category 2 [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. You can tell it is not Category 1 because Category 1 is driven by permission to Accept Deposits or to Manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account that is a PSIAu (and not meeting Category 5), which is a different determinative permission set from Category 2 [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66].
source_text:
An Authorised Person is in Category 2 if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal);
(b)	its dealing activities are not limited in scope as provided in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i); and
(c)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5.
Category 3A
Guidance
A Category 3A Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3A. Provided that an Authorised Person carries out the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Agent in a manner that is wholly incidental to the activity of Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets, the Authorised Person shall be regarded as falling within Category 3C.
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: When is the Regulator permitted to require a Person to pay a supplementary fee, and how do the triggers differ between a particularly complex or novel waiver or modification request and situations involving additional cost or effort for an application, authorisation, filing, or on-going supervision?
gold_answer: Across both provisions, the Regulator is permitted to require a Person to pay a supplementary fee, but the circumstances that can justify the requirement are framed differently and should be assessed against the relevant trigger. Under the SOURCE, the supplementary fee power is tied specifically to a request for a waiver or modification, and it may be imposed where, in the opinion of the Regulator, that request is particularly complex or novel [#SRC:ef45697b-2b10-450b-bacc-b9d501e87404]. Under the TARGET, the same type of fee may be required in a broader set of regulatory interactions where the Regulator expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort, including when dealing with an application, authorisation, filing, or when conducting on-going supervision [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. Read together, a supplementary fee may be justified either by the nature of a waiver/modification request (complexity/novelty) or by the Regulator’s expected incremental cost/effort in handling specified processes or supervision, with the Regulator as the decision-maker in each case.
source_text: In accordance with Rule 1.2.4, the Regulator may require a Person to pay a supplementary fee where the request for a waiver or modification is particularly complex or novel in the opinion of the Regulator.
target_text:
Supplementary fees
The Regulator may require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee in circumstances where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing or when conducting on-going supervision.

question: If a Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund wants to do the Fund’s administration work itself, what must it ensure about risk management and portfolio functions, and what is it required to do about the Fund’s operational risks given the roles of Fund Administrators, Eligible Custodians, and any prime brokers?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund is permitted to perform fund administration for the Fund, but only where risk management and portfolio functions are adequately separated, so the Fund Manager must first ensure that this separation exists in the circumstances in which it takes on administration tasks [#SRC:5cba2a1e-1340-4401-a5c7-23c937abe4fc]. Separately and in all cases, the Fund Manager must ensure that the risks inherent in the operation of a Fund are adequately addressed, with due regard to the nature of the strategies and investment process it employs and the role of Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians and, where appointed, prime brokers [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7]. Putting these together, doing administration in-house does not reduce the Fund Manager’s responsibility for operational risk; instead, the Fund Manager must structure its internal functions so that risk management remains adequately separated from portfolio functions while also considering how administration, custody, and any prime brokerage roles affect how operational risks are addressed in practice.
source_text: A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund may be able to perform fund administration for the Fund in circumstances where risk management and portfolio functions are adequately separated (Rule 12.3.10).
target_text: Risk management. A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund must ensure that the risks inherent in the operation of a Fund are adequately addressed, with due regard to the nature of the strategies and investment process employed by the Fund Manager and the role of Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians and where appointed, prime brokers.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information under Rule 11.9.1 and treats its material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive, what specific statements and explanatory content must it provide, and how does that disclosure need to connect to the Production Target from which the forecast is derived (including the Rule 11.8.3 information)?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that discloses forecast financial information under Rule 11.9.1 must still provide a complete, investor-understandable explanation of how its forecast is built, even if it treats material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In that scenario, it must (i) identify all material economic assumptions used, and (ii) if it considers those assumptions commercially sensitive, include an explicit statement that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine them. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Where it relies on the relevant guidance, it must also explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive and disclose enough information—potentially using narrative rather than numbers—to allow investors to understand the methodology used to determine the factors and assumptions and the basis for reporting estimates of Ore Reserves. [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80] Separately, the Rule 11.9.1 disclosure must identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived and include all information required by Rule 11.8.3 for that Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] The commercially sensitive treatment does not remove the need to provide sufficient methodological context for investors, including the basis for Ore Reserves estimates. [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80]
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text:
ORE RESERVES. In such cases, however, where a Mining Reporting Entity relies on the guidance set out in Rule 11.6.1(1)(a), it:

a)	must make a statement to the effect that its material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive;

b)	should explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive; and

c)	must disclose sufficient information (possibly in narrative rather than numerical form, where the numbers are commercially sensitive) in order for investors to understand the methodology it has used to determine these factors and assumptions, and the basis on which it is reporting the estimates of Ore Reserves.

question: If an Authorised Person is going to put Client Money into a Client Account with a Third-Party Agent, what does the Third-Party Agent’s written acknowledgment need to say, and does that acknowledgment need to be kept in the Resolution Pack?
gold_answer: Before the Authorised Person deposits Client Money into a Client Account that is established with a Third-Party Agent, it must first get a written acknowledgment from that Third-Party Agent. [#TGT:4b3b6294-0035-4dd7-b254-827c825338b9] The acknowledgment has to confirm that the Money in the account is held by the Authorised Person for its Clients, and it must also confirm the Third-Party Agent cannot merge that account with other accounts or use the Money as security or to set off or counterclaim against debts the Authorised Person owes the Third-Party Agent. [#TGT:4b3b6294-0035-4dd7-b254-827c825338b9] Separately, the Authorised Person’s Resolution Pack must include records covering Third-Party Agent acknowledgment in respect of Client Money. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] Putting these together, the written acknowledgment you obtain as a condition of depositing Client Money should be retained in a way that allows it to be included within the Resolution Pack record set for Third-Party Agent acknowledgment relating to Client Money, along with the other Resolution Pack items required for Client Money and Client Investments (for example, master lists of Client Accounts and the most recent reconciliations). [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]
target_text: Before depositing Client Money in a Client Account established with a Third-Party Agent, it must obtain a written acknowledgment from the Third-Party Agent stating that all Money standing to the credit of the account is held by the Authorised Person on behalf of its Clients and that the Third-Party Agent is not entitled to combine the account with any other account, or exercise any charge, mortgage, security, lien, right of set-off or combination or counterclaim against Money in that account in respect of any sum owed to it by the Authorised Person.

question: When a law enforcement agency seeks a person’s interview answers for use in criminal proceedings against that person, what is the Investigator prohibited from doing, and how does the Regulator’s general practice of notifying the person fit into the permitted pathways for any disclosure?
gold_answer: Where a law enforcement agency requests a person’s answers from an interview conducted under the relevant compulsory questioning power for use in criminal proceedings against that person, the Investigator is prohibited from disclosing the statement to the law enforcement agency unless one of two conditions is met: the person consents to the disclosure, or the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff]. In parallel, when the Regulator receives such a request, the Regulator generally notifies the person concerned so the person has an opportunity to either consent to the disclosure or challenge the request, which operationally supports the consent-based exception and provides a procedural opportunity before disclosure occurs [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951]. However, that notification practice is qualified: it does not displace the prohibition on disclosure, and it may not apply where the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement, in which case disclosure may proceed under the legal compulsion exception [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff].
source_text: If the Regulator receives a request from a law enforcement agency for a person's answers in an interview conducted under section 206(1)(a) of the FSMR for the purpose of criminal proceedings against the person, the Regulator will, in accordance with section 207(2) of the FSMR, generally notify the person concerned of such request (so that the person has an opportunity to either consent to the disclosure or challenge the request), unless the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.
target_text:
The Investigator shall not disclose a statement made by a person in answer to any question asked pursuant to a requirement made of the person under section ‎206‎(1)‎(a) to any law enforcement agency for the purpose of criminal proceedings against the person unless—
(a)	the person consents to the disclosure; or
(b)	the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.

question: What must be included in the first Production Target disclosure, and what extra steps let a Mining Reporting Entity avoid repeating that same information in a later Production Target disclosure?
gold_answer: For the first disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2, the Mining Reporting Entity must include required information about the assumptions used to determine the Production Target, including all material economic assumptions (or, if it considers them commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine them) and all other material assumptions utilised; it must also include other required Production Target items such as any statement that forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds, the proportions of the Production Target based on different categories (including Inferred Mineral Resources and any Exploration Target), and the required statements addressing viability and the required cautionary statements where applicable [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. After that, a later disclosure in relation to the Production Target is allowed to leave out the information that would otherwise have to be disclosed again, but only if the Mining Reporting Entity references the earlier disclosure that was compliant with those information requirements and includes a confirmation that all the material assumptions in the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]. If the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement to the relevant effect [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef].
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: Where a Listed Entity qualifies for admission to the Official List and meets the Regulator’s profitability/revenue or tangible-asset criteria so that APP 7 category restrictions are disapplied unless the Regulator decides otherwise, may a Controller also be treated as not needing to be a party to the relevant Restriction Agreement, and on what bases?
gold_answer: Yes, these provisions can operate together, but they address different compliance outcomes. Under the TARGET, unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that qualifies for admission to the Official List and either has a track record of profitability or revenue acceptable to the Regulator, or (in the Regulator’s opinion) has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value forming a substantial proportion of total assets [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]. Separately, under the SOURCE, a Controller need not be a party to the Restriction Agreement if any specified condition applies, including where the value of the Restricted Security is less than 10% of the total value of the assets of the holder of the Restricted Securities or an intermediate entity through which the Controller has its interests; where the holder or such intermediate entity is a Listed Entity (or listed on an exchange that is a full member of the World Federation of Exchanges) or is a trustee, custodian or nominee; or where the holder is a Person whose Securities are Restricted Securities due to category 2, 4 or 6 of APP 7 [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010].
source_text:
Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. A Controller need not be a party to the Restriction Agreement referred to in Rule 9.6.2 if any of the following applies.
(1)	The value of the Restricted Security is less than 10% of the total value of the assets of:
(a)	the holder of the Restricted Securities; or
(b)	an intermediate entity through which the Controller has its interests.
(2)	The holder, or an intermediate entity through which the Controller has its interests, is:
(a)	a Listed Entity, or an entity listed on exchange that is a full member of the World Federation of Exchanges; or
(b)	a trustee, custodian or nominee.
(3)	The holder is a Person whose Securities are Restricted Securities due to the application of category 2, 4 or 6 of APP 7.
target_text:
Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. Unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that:
(1)	qualifies for admission to the Official List pursuant to Rule 2.3.15;
(2)	has a track record of profitability or revenue acceptable to the Regulator; or
(3)	in the opinion of the Regulator, has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value which constitute a substantial proportion of the total value of its assets.

question: If a Fund Manager runs an ADGM Green Fund, what part of the Fund’s property needs an ongoing and at least annual third-party attestation, and when can the Fund Manager avoid appointing a third party (either by self-attesting for a Qualified Investor Fund or because the assets track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark)?
gold_answer: As a baseline, the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must appoint a third party to attest to compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually, but only for a defined slice of the Fund’s holdings. [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] Specifically, the requirement is limited to the portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy (the taxonomy-aligned portion described in connection with Rule 20.2.3(a)). [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] There are two ways the Fund Manager can avoid appointing a third party: (1) if the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager chooses to provide the attestation itself, then a third-party appointment is not required because the Fund Manager performs the attestation. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0] (2) if all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark (linked to Rule 20.2.3(b)), then no attestation is required at all. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0]
source_text: The Green Fund Attestation Requirement. Subject to Rule 20.2.9, the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually.  This requirement only applies to that portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy in accordance with Rule ‎20.2.3(a). This is referred to as the “Green Fund Attestation Requirement”.
target_text:
Alternative Attestation Requirement. The Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund is not required to appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement if:
(a)	the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager elects to provide the attestation itself; or
(b)	all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark pursuant to Rule ‎20.2.3(b), in which event an attestation is not required.

question: If an Issuer wants its Securities admitted to trading on an MTF and plans an Exempt Offer to up to 200 people who are not Professional Clients, what extra condition about where/how the Securities are offered must be met, and can the Issuer also offer to Professional Clients at the same time?
gold_answer: For an Issuer that is seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF, an Exempt Offer can be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients as part of that MTF-related scenario. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] To fit within the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for this 200-person approach, the offer must be in or from the ADGM, must be directed at no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients (and not Market Counterparties), and it must occur in circumstances where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] Alongside that capped offer to non-Professional Clients, the Issuer can also run a simultaneous Exempt Offer to Professional Clients, which is described as allowing an unlimited number of Professional Clients under the Professional Client-only circumstance. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] In other words, the Issuer can split the offering into two tranches—one limited to 200 non-Professional Clients under the MTF-linked route, and another directed only at Professional Clients—so long as the MTF/Private Financing Platform condition for the 200-person tranche is satisfied. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc]
source_text: MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) provides for the specific circumstance where an Exempt Offer can be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients, where the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF.  An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in accordance with MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) may also, pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.3, utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more of the circumstances within MKT Rule 4.3.1, with the exception of MKT Rule 4.3.1(2).  For example, an Issuer may make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to 200 Persons under MKT rule 4.3.1(13), and an unlimited number of Professional Clients under MKT Rule 4.3.1(1).

question: When calculating Exposure value for on-balance sheet derivatives (including written credit protection), how must a firm determine the components that are summed (IFRS on-balance sheet amount plus a potential future exposure add-on), and how must that approach be aligned with the requirement to calculate replacement cost and potential future exposure differently for margined versus unmargined netting sets, including the cap applicable to a margined netting set’s EAD?
gold_answer: For on-balance sheet derivatives, including written credit protection, the firm must calculate the Exposure value as a sum of two elements: (i) the on-balance sheet value determined in accordance with IFRS and (ii) an add-on for potential future exposure calculated under the specified App 4 rules [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007]. In applying the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk for derivatives and long settlement transactions, the firm must ensure that the replacement cost (RC) and potential future exposure (PFE) components used in its counterparty credit risk framework are calculated differently depending on whether the relevant netting set is margined or unmargined [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941]. Where the exposure is measured on a margined netting set basis, the firm must also apply the constraint that the EAD for that margined netting set is capped at the EAD of the same netting set calculated on an unmargined basis [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941]. Together, these requirements mean the summed Exposure value for derivatives must incorporate an IFRS-based amount plus a PFE add-on, while the PFE (and RC) mechanics and any EAD cap must reflect whether netting is treated as margined or unmargined.
source_text:
In relation to on-balance sheet items:
a.	for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14;
b.	for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and
c.	for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.
target_text: Derivatives and long settlement transactions – Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR). The replacement cost (RC) and the potential future exposure (PFE) components must be calculated differently for margined and unmargined netting sets. The EAD for a margined netting set is to be capped at the EAD of the same netting set calculated on an unmargined basis.

question: If an Authorised Person runs an MTF or an OTF, which MIR rulebook sections does it have to follow as if it were a Recognised Body/Recognised Investment Exchange, and when COBS Chapter 8 is being read for Rules 22.7.1 and 22.7.2, what words should it swap in for “Investments” and “Financial Instruments” (including where MIR comes in through COBS Rule 8.2.1)?
gold_answer: If the Authorised Person is an MTF Operator or OTF Operator, it must follow certain MIR rulebook requirements that normally apply to a Recognised Body or Recognised Investment Exchange, but it must read those references as if they refer to the MTF Operator or OTF Operator itself. [#TGT:180edda8-db12-4969-97d5-182435bdf094] Separately, when interpreting COBS Chapter 8 for the purposes of Rules 22.7.1 and 22.7.2, it must adjust the meaning of key product terms: references to “Investment(s)” are to be treated as references to “Spot Commodity/Spot Commodities,” and references to “Financial Instrument(s)”—including where those terms appear in MIR text that is brought in via COBS Rule 8.2.1—are to be treated as references to “Accepted Spot Commodity/Accepted Spot Commodities,” as applicable. [#SRC:27f8e3fb-1055-4605-bb11-0b75eba743c2] The MIR sections the MTF Operator or OTF Operator must comply with under the read-across are MIR 2.6, MIR 2.7.1 and 2.7.2, MIR 2.8, MIR 2.9, MIR 2.11, MIR 3.3, MIR 3.5, MIR 3.6, MIR 3.7, MIR 3.8, MIR 3.10, and MIR 3.11. [#TGT:180edda8-db12-4969-97d5-182435bdf094] Putting these together means the firm both (i) applies the listed MIR obligations in the correct “as if” capacity and (ii) uses the commodity-based term substitutions when COBS Chapter 8 is the interpretive frame for those specific COBS rules. [#TGT:180edda8-db12-4969-97d5-182435bdf094] [#SRC:27f8e3fb-1055-4605-bb11-0b75eba743c2]
source_text:
For the purposes of Rules 22.7.1 and 22.7.2, the following references in COBS, Chapter 8 should be read as follows:
(a)	references to “Investment” or “Investments” shall be read as references to “Spot Commodity” or “Spot Commodities”, and
(b)	references to “Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments” (including those in MIR as incorporated by virtue of COBS Rule 8.2.1) shall be read as references to “Accepted Spot Commodity” or “Accepted Spot Commodities” as applicable.

question: For a Petroleum Reporting Entity preparing a Summary of Reserves and Resources, when must it include the MKT Form 12-1 table and what is the relevant “as of” date constraint, and how does this change if the entity is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity generally must include, within its Summary of Reserves and Resources, a table using the MKT Form 12-1 format, and that table must be prepared “as of” a date that is no earlier than one month before the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed. [#SRC:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] However, if the Petroleum Reporting Entity is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC, it is not required to comply with Rule 12.14.1, which is the rule that imposes the MKT Form 12-1 table requirement and its timing condition. [#TGT:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1] In practical terms, the compliance outcome depends on whether the entity falls into that SEC annual filing category: if it does not, it must include the MKT Form 12-1 table and ensure the “as of” date is within the one-month window before disclosure; if it does, the entity is exempt from the Rule 12.14.1 obligation and therefore does not have to meet that table-inclusion requirement or its associated “as of” date constraint under that rule. [#SRC:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] [#TGT:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1]
source_text: Subject to Rule 12.14.3, a Petroleum Reporting Entity must include in its Summary of Reserves and Resources a table in the form of MKT Form 12-1, as of a date no earlier than one month prior to the disclosure of the Summary of Reserves and Resources.
target_text: A Petroleum Reporting Entity that is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC is not required to comply with Rule 12.14.1.

question: If a Payment Service Provider is preparing a Framework Contract and also intends to satisfy the Single Payment Service Contract pre-binding disclosure by supplying a draft Payment Order, which specific information items must be covered in the pre-binding disclosure and which additional Framework Contract items must still be included (particularly around consent procedure and cut-off/time-of-receipt concepts)?
gold_answer: Using a draft Payment Order as the delivery method does not change the minimum content that must be provided before the Payment Service User is bound by the Single Payment Service Contract, and it does not remove the need for the Framework Contract to contain its broader set of mandatory terms. [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55] For the Single Payment Service Contract, the Payment Service Provider must provide or make available, before the Payment Service User is bound, the information/unique identifier the Payment Service User must provide for proper initiation or execution, the maximum execution time, the charges payable (with a breakdown where applicable), and—where applicable—the actual or Reference Exchange Rate to be applied. [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55] Separately, the Framework Contract must include additional operational and procedural information beyond those pre-binding items, including the form and procedure for giving consent to initiation/execution and for withdrawing consent, as well as the time of receipt of a Payment Order and any cut-off time for processing established by the Payment Service Provider. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] The Framework Contract must also include the required charges and exchange-rate disclosures (including, where relevant, the method for determining the relevant date for Reference Exchange Rates). [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]

question: For a Third Party Provider’s Governing Contract, how should the contract’s required exchange-rate disclosures and any agreed approach to changing exchange rates be structured so that the provider can apply exchange-rate changes immediately and without notice only in the permitted cases?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider should draft the Governing Contract so that (i) it includes the required baseline disclosures on exchange rates and (ii) it only permits immediate, no-notice exchange-rate changes in the limited situations allowed. The contract must, where relevant, state the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are used, explain how the relevant date is determined for those Reference Exchange Rates. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Where relevant and if agreed, it must also address how changes in Reference Exchange Rates will be applied and what information will be provided in relation to those changes. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Against that disclosure framework, immediate application without notice is only appropriate where the Governing Contract expressly grants that right and the exchange-rate changes are based on Reference Exchange Rate information that has already been provided to the Customer in accordance with Rule 20.2.2, or where the change is more favourable to the Customer. [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] In practice, this means the contract’s “changes” provisions should be aligned with its exchange-rate/Reference Exchange Rate disclosures so the no-notice mechanism is not broader than these two permitted cases. [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]
source_text:
Changes in contractual information. Changes in exchange rates may be applied immediately and without notice where:
(a)	such a right is agreed under the Governing Contract and any such changes in exchange rates are based on the Reference Exchange Rate information which has been provided to the Customer in accordance with Rule 20.2.2; or
(b)	the changes are more favourable to the Customer.

question: If an Authorised Person is doing Regulated Activities and also putting out Investment Research, who does it need to check for conflicts under Principle 7 (Rule 2.2.7), and what extra control requirement applies to the Investment Research itself?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must run a conflicts check that matches Principle 7 in Rule 2.2.7 and, at the same time, ensure it has adequate procedures and controls for the Investment Research it prepares or publishes. [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] The conflicts check is not limited to obvious issues; it requires taking all reasonable steps to identify conflicts that arise or may arise while the Authorised Person is providing any Regulated Activities. [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] When doing that identification, the Authorised Person must look for conflicts between (1) the Authorised Person (including its managers, Employees and Clients, and any person directly or indirectly linked to them by control) and a Client, and (2) one Client and another Client. [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] In addition to identifying conflicts, the Authorised Person is expected to take reasonable steps to prevent or manage actual or potential conflicts, and this obligation sits alongside the separate requirement for adequate procedures and controls around Investment Research. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]
source_text: The requirements in this Rule ‎6.4.2 apply to an Authorised Person in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any rules made thereunder. For example, an Authorised Person is required to take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them under GEN 3.3.21-3.3.24. An Authorised Person must also have adequate procedures and controls when it prepares or publishes Investment Research.
target_text:
Conflicts of Interest: An Authorised Person must comply with Principle 7 as outlined in Rule ‎2.2.7, taking all reasonable steps to identify conflicts of interest between:
(1)	the Authorised Person, including its managers, Employees and Clients, or any person directly or indirectly linked to them by control; or
(2)	one Client of the Authorised Person and another Client,
that arises or may arise in the course of the Authorised Person providing any Regulated Activities.

question: When may the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund avoid appointing a third party to attest to compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement, given the general obligation to obtain ongoing and at least annual attestation for the relevant portion of Eligible Green Fund Property?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund generally must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually, but this obligation is limited in scope: it only applies to the portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy. [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] However, the Fund Manager may avoid appointing a third party where the Alternative Attestation Requirement applies. Specifically, a third-party attestation is not required if the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager elects to provide the attestation itself, which substitutes for the otherwise required third-party appointment. Alternatively, no attestation is required at all if all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark. In that benchmark-tracking scenario, the exemption removes the need for any attestation notwithstanding the general ongoing and annual third-party framework. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0]
source_text: The Green Fund Attestation Requirement. Subject to Rule 20.2.9, the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually.  This requirement only applies to that portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy in accordance with Rule ‎20.2.3(a). This is referred to as the “Green Fund Attestation Requirement”.
target_text:
Alternative Attestation Requirement. The Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund is not required to appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement if:
(a)	the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager elects to provide the attestation itself; or
(b)	all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark pursuant to Rule ‎20.2.3(b), in which event an attestation is not required.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity talks again about the same Non-Equivalent Estimates after an earlier compliant announcement, what does it have to include in the later disclosure to avoid repeating all the detailed items, and what key statement still has to be made for material Non-Equivalent Estimates?
gold_answer: For any disclosure of material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, a Mining Reporting Entity must include the required package of information, starting with a prominent, nearby statement explaining that the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates not disclosed under a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done enough work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, and that it is uncertain they will ever be able to be disclosed as such, plus the other required details (such as sources/dates, relevance, reliability, summaries of work and assumptions, any newer data, what work is needed to verify, timing and funding, the standard used, and a named Competent Person statement for specified items) [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]. If the Mining Reporting Entity previously made a disclosure that complied with those requirements, then in a later disclosure about the same Non-Equivalent Estimates it does not need to repeat the full information, but only if it points back to the earlier compliant disclosure, confirms the earlier information still applies, confirms there is no new material information or data affecting reliability/interpretation or the ability to verify the estimates under a Mining Reporting Standard, and includes an equally prominent, nearby statement addressing the same matters as the required prominent statement [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4].
source_text:
If a Mining Reporting Entity has disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates that comply with the requirements of Rule 11.7.3, then any subsequent disclosure made in respect of the Non-Equivalent Estimates does not need to include the information in that Rule if the subsequent disclosure:
(1)	references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with that Rule;
(2)	contains a confirmation from the Mining Reporting Entity that:
(a)	the information provided in the earlier disclosure in compliance with that Rule continues to apply; and
(b)	there is no new material information or data relating to the Non-Equivalent Estimates that impacts on the:
(i)	reliability or interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates; or
(ii)	Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; and
(3)	includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates addressing the matters contained in Rule 11.7.3(1).

question: When an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction is confirmed, under what circumstances is the Third Party Provider required to make the refund by the stated deadline, and when is that refund-timing requirement excluded because of suspected Customer fraud?
gold_answer: Where the Third Party Provider has confirmed that a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it is required to provide a refund as soon as practicable and, at the latest, by the end of the day following the day of that confirmation [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]. However, the scope of the refund-timing requirement is limited: the requirement to provide a refund within the prescribed timeframe does not apply where the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012]. Read together, the obligation is that the Third Party Provider must proceed with the refund promptly once it has confirmed the transaction status, but it is not bound by the prescribed refund timeframe if it can point to reasonable grounds for suspecting Customer fraud. In practice, this means the Third Party Provider should (i) document the confirmation that the transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, and (ii) separately assess and record whether it has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer, because that suspicion affects whether the prescribed refund timeframe applies.
source_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. The requirement to provide a refund within the timeframe prescribed in Rule 20.12.2 does not apply where the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer.
target_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. The Third Party Provider must provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 as soon as practicable, and in any event no later than the end of the day following the day on which it has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed.

question: If a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund, what must it do, and how can the Regulator’s discretion to direct the establishment of one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds affect the Captive Insurer’s available compliance options?
gold_answer: Where a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund, it has a mandatory choice: it must either establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds or notify the Regulator in writing that the Captive Insurer is deemed to constitute a single Long-Term Insurance Fund [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469]. Separately, the Regulator has residual discretion and may, at its sole discretion, direct that a Captive Insurer which conducts Long-Term Insurance Business establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds in respect of its Long-Term Insurance Business or any part of such business [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7]. Read together, the Captive Insurer’s obligation to choose between establishing funds or providing the written notification operates as the baseline compliance requirement, but the Regulator’s discretionary power can require establishment of one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds notwithstanding that baseline. Accordingly, even if the Captive Insurer would otherwise prefer to rely on the written notification that it is deemed a single Long-Term Insurance Fund, it must be prepared to comply with a direction to establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds for the relevant business or part of it.
source_text:
Residual discretion of the Regulator
Notwithstanding Rule 8.1.1 and 8.1.2, the Regulator may, at its sole discretion, direct that a Captive Insurer which conducts Long-Term Insurance Business establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds in respect of its Long-Term Insurance Business or any part of such business.
target_text:
Captive Insurer not a Cell Company
Where a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that, under the provisions of Rule ‎8.2, must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund, it must either:
(a)	establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds; or
(b)	notify the Regulator in writing that the Captive Insurer is deemed to constitute a single Long-Term Insurance Fund.

question: If an Authorised Person can provide custody for a Fund or act as trustee of an Investment Trust, when would it still be treated as Category 1 instead of Category 3B?
gold_answer: Even if an Authorised Person’s Financial Services Permission authorises it to provide custody for a Fund or act as the Trustee of an Investment Trust, it will not be Category 3B if it meets the criteria of Category 1, because Category 3B requires that the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5 [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe]. Category 1 is triggered when the Financial Services Permission authorises the firm to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Category 5; the guidance explains that this authorisation is determinative of Category 1 even if the firm is also authorised for other Regulated Activities [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. So, a custody/trustee firm would still be treated as Category 1 if its permission also includes Accepting Deposits or Managing a PSIAu and it is not in Category 5, because that makes it meet Category 1 and therefore fail the “not Category 1” condition needed for Category 3B.
source_text:
Category 3B
An Authorised Person is in Category 3B if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of:
(i)	Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund); or
(ii)	Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust; and
(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5.
Guidance
A Category 3B Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Providing Custody for a Fund or Acting as Trustee of a Fund, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1, 1.3.2 and 1.3.3 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3B.
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: If an Authorised Person has both SE Exposures and Early Amortisation Exposures, what steps does it follow to work out the risk-weighted amounts for each type, and how are the two sets of results added together?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must calculate risk-weighted Exposure amounts separately for SE Exposures and for Early Amortisation Exposures, and then add the totals together as part of the overall securitisation-related RWA calculation. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] For SE Exposures, it must measure each Exposure value using the Section 4.9 methodology while recognising any applicable CRM, allocate a Credit Quality Grade under Section 4.11, and then compute RWA(SE) = SE × CRW, where CRW is the risk weight that corresponds to that Credit Quality Grade. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] For Early Amortisation Exposures, it must measure each Exposure value (EAE) using the same Section 4.9 methodology and CRM recognition, and then compute RWA(EAE) = EAE × CRW. [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e] The key difference is that, for Early Amortisation Exposures, CRW is taken from the underlying Exposure type as though the Exposure had not been securitised, rather than being derived from a Credit Quality Grade. [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e] After calculating each set, it must sum the RWA(EAE) amounts across all Early Amortisation Exposures and add that sum to the RWA(SE) amounts calculated for its SE Exposures (excluding any SE Exposures required to be deducted from Capital Resources). [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e]

(b)	calculate the risk weighted Exposure amount for each Early Amortisation Exposure using the following formula: RWA(EAE) = EAE x CRW
where:
(i)	"RWA(EAE)" refers to the risk weighted Exposure amount for that Early Amortisation Exposure;
(ii)	"EAE" refers to the Exposure value or amount, for that Early Amortisation Exposure calculated in accordance with (a); and
(iii)	"CRW" refers to the applicable risk weight for the underlying Exposure type as if the Exposure had not been securitised; and
(c)	add the RWA amounts calculated in accordance with (b) for all its Early Amortisation Exposures.

question: If a Listed Entity enters into an agreement to issue Equity Securities that is expressly conditional on the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities approving the issue under Rule 9.7.1 before the issue is made, how does that approval condition interact with (i) the requirement to obtain holder approval when the 20% formula cap would otherwise be exceeded and (ii) the treatment of such approved issues in calculating “Relevant Issues” for the 12‑month formula?
gold_answer: Where the Listed Entity uses an agreement to issue Equity Securities that is conditional on holder approval under Rule 9.7.1, it cannot proceed to issue the Equity Securities unless that approval is obtained, because the condition is a mandatory precondition to issuing under that exception. [#SRC:6f5d3058-de98-48a8-a8dc-2e4967c6a437] Separately, the Listed Entity must obtain approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities if it would otherwise issue or agree to issue more Equity Securities than permitted by the formula “(20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues.” [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Once approval under Rule 9.7.1 is obtained, the approved issue (or agreement to issue) is treated as excluded from “Relevant Issues,” because Relevant Issues do not include Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued with holder approval under Rule 9.7.1 (or Rule 9.7.5). [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] In practical terms, the Rule 9.7.1 approval both (i) satisfies the condition required to actually issue under the conditional agreement and (ii) prevents that approved issuance/agreement from counting toward Relevant Issues in the 12‑month calculation, which can affect whether the formula cap would be exceeded. [#SRC:6f5d3058-de98-48a8-a8dc-2e4967c6a437] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]
source_text: An agreement to issue Equity Securities that is conditional on the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities approving the issue under Rule 9.7.1 before the issue is made.  If a Listed Entity relies on this exception, it must not issue the Equity Securities without such approval.
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: When an Authorised Person is determining the Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by applying jurisdictional buffer rates to its private sector credit exposures, how should it identify which exposures qualify as “private sector credit exposures,” and what quantitative base must those rates be applied to?
gold_answer: To calculate the Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital, an Authorised Person must first ensure it is using the correct population of “private sector credit exposures” for determining which jurisdictions’ countercyclical buffer rates apply, and then apply the resulting weighted average rate to the required quantitative base. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] “Private sector credit exposures” are specifically those exposures for which Credit RWAs must be calculated under Chapter 4, but excluding exposures that fall within the listed asset classes (Central government and central bank, Public sector enterprises, Multilateral development bank (MDB), International organisation, and Bank). [#TGT:5d947e78-d9be-42d5-aad3-95b3528ea88c] Once the Authorised Person has identified the relevant private sector credit exposures and the jurisdictions where those exposures are located (so that the applicable jurisdictional buffer rates can be weighted and averaged), the buffer amount must be computed as the Total Risk Exposure Amount (as calculated under Rule 3.5.7) multiplied by that weighted average of the applicable countercyclical buffer rates (as calculated under Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8). [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]
source_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.
target_text:
Private sector credit exposures. Private sector credit exposures are those for which Credit RWAs have to be calculated in accordance with Chapter 4, other than those that fall into the following asset classes:
(a)	Central government and central bank.
(b)	Public sector enterprises.
(c)	Multilateral development bank (MDB).
(d)	International organisation.
(e)	Bank.

question: When a decision made under these Regulations by the Regulator, or Rules made by the Regulator, may affect a person’s rights or liabilities or otherwise adversely affect that person’s interests, is that person permitted to refer the matter to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review, and are any categories of decisions excluded from referral under the broader framework described?
gold_answer: Yes. Where a decision made under these Regulations by the Regulator, or Rules made by the Regulator, may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect that person’s interests, that person may refer the decision to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23]. The broader framework described alongside this permission indicates that the referral right is framed to cover decisions that may affect rights or liabilities or otherwise adversely affect interests, but it also notes an exclusion for operational decisions from the set of decisions that may be referred for a full merits review [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]. In addition, the framework explains that certain other decisions—specifically including decisions such as the exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers—may also be referable to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review even where they are not subject to the Part 21 procedure [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]. Taken together, the permission to refer in the Regulations operates for affected persons, while the broader description clarifies both an operational-decision carve-out and that some additional non‑Part 21 decisions may still be referable.
source_text: Section 225(1) of FSMR provides that all of our decisions that may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect the interests of a person (except operational decisions) may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review. FSMR also specifies that certain other decisions, not subject to the Part 21 procedure, may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review (e.g., exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers).
target_text: Any decision made under these Regulations by the Regulator or Rules made by the Regulator which may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect the interests of a person, may be referred by that person to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review .

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has already made one compliant disclosure and then later talks again about forecast financial information based on a Production Target, what does it have to say in the later disclosure, and what information can it avoid repeating from the earlier Production Target disclosure?
gold_answer: In a later disclosure about forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, a Mining Reporting Entity can avoid repeating the full set of detailed Production Target disclosure information, but only if specific conditions are met. The later disclosure must refer back to the earlier disclosure that contained the required Production Target assumption information, and it must include a confirmation that all material assumptions used for the initial forecast financial information still apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. The earlier disclosure it references must have included the required content for a Production Target disclosure, including the material economic assumptions (or a statement that they are commercially sensitive plus the methodology used), all other material assumptions, and (if forecast commodity prices were used) a statement that the forecast pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds, as well as the proportions of the Production Target attributable to the specified reserve/resource categories and any Exploration Target component [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. Also, the later disclosure must still include an equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement when the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, and must do the same when the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4].
