(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: When an Authorised Person has failed to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, how must it treat proposed CET1 Capital-related actions that fall within the meaning of a distribution (including cash dividends, bonus Shares, or a redemption or purchase of its own Shares), and what calculation and notification steps must occur before any such action may be undertaken?
gold_answer: A distribution in connection with CET1 Capital is defined broadly to capture multiple forms of value transfer or capital reduction, including payment of cash dividends, distribution of fully or partly paid bonus Shares or other capital instruments, a redemption or purchase by an institution of its own Shares or other capital instruments, repayment of amounts paid up in connection with capital, and other items eligible for inclusion as CET1 Capital [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26]. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must first calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with the applicable rule and, until it has both calculated that amount and notified the Regulator, it must ensure it does not make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital (as defined) [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]. This restriction also applies to creating an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, and to paying variable remuneration where the obligation was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement, as well as to making payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e].
target_text:
Restrictions on distributions. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must:
(a)	calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and

(i)	make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, or create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement; or
(ii)	make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments.

question: If an Authorised Person is arranging professional indemnity insurance, what should the policy cover (including whose conduct and legal costs), what kind of Insurer should it be with, and what does the Authorised Person have to send or report to the Regulator each year and when the cover changes?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must keep professional indemnity insurance that matches the nature, size, complexity and risk profile of its business, and it should do so through a contract placed with a reputable and well capitalised Insurer. [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b] [#SRC:3c5ec7af-6f4a-41d7-988c-13494992bc71] The insurance contract should be written so it covers claims where the Authorised Person could be liable because of the conduct of the Authorised Person itself and its Employees, and it should also include appropriate cover for legal costs that come from a claim. [#SRC:3c5ec7af-6f4a-41d7-988c-13494992bc71] Beyond buying and keeping the cover, the Authorised Person must provide the Regulator with a copy of the insurance cover at least annually, and that copy must cover the following 12-month period. [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b] The Authorised Person must also be able to demonstrate that the cover is adequate against the same business risk-profile factors, and it must notify the Regulator of any material changes to the cover, including changes in the level of cover and whether the cover is renewed or terminated. [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b]

question: When a Listed Entity has already issued, or agreed to issue, Equity Securities without prior holder approval, in what circumstances is that action treated as if it had been approved, and how does that treatment interact with the prohibition on exceeding the maximum number of Equity Securities that may be issued without holder approval (including the calculation inputs that exclude or include prior issues)?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity is prohibited from issuing, or agreeing to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the specified formula unless it has the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities, and the calculation depends on both the Base Amount and the subtraction of Relevant Issues [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. If an issue (or agreement to issue) was made without the required approval, it can be treated as having been made with approval for the relevant approval purposes only if three conditions are met: it did not exceed the applicable limit, the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities subsequently approve it, and the Securities are issued within three months of that approval [#SRC:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6]. This “treated as approved” status matters to the prohibition and its formula because the Target’s calculation expressly treats certain prior issues differently depending on whether they were approved (or taken under the Rules to have been approved) under the relevant approval framework: approved issues can be included in the Base Amount in specified cases and are excluded from Relevant Issues, whereas unapproved issues generally remain part of Relevant Issues and therefore reduce remaining capacity under the maximum.

(2)	the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities subsequently approve it; and
(3)	the Securities are issued within three months of the date of the approval.

question: In what circumstances may the Regulator grant a waiver for Financial Instruments, where the waiver is framed by the market model and the type of order or transaction, and how do those grounds align with waivers available for instruments not otherwise covered, including large-in-scale orders and orders held pending disclosure by the Recognised Investment Exchange?
gold_answer: Across both provisions, the Regulator is the decision-maker that may grant waivers in respect of Financial Instruments, but the permissible grounds differ in emphasis and should be read together to understand the full scope. The SOURCE focuses on Financial Instruments not otherwise covered and permits waivers for three situations: orders that are large in scale compared with normal market size, orders held in an order management facility of the Recognised Investment Exchange pending disclosure, and Financial Instruments for which there is not a liquid market [#SRC:63e56280-5a41-48fb-a327-25aebcb4834a]. The TARGET adds a market-model and transaction-type framework, allowing waivers where systems match orders using a reference price from another venue or relevant liquid market, where systems formalise negotiated transactions subject to specified pricing/volume safeguards or pre-set reference parameters, and it also repeats the large-in-scale and pending-disclosure order-management-facility grounds [#TGT:aa29640b-f2f9-435b-8e56-31e99fff54e6]. Taken together, a waiver request can be grounded either in the nature of the order (large-in-scale; held pending disclosure) or in the trading methodology/transaction structure (reference-price matching; formalised negotiated transactions), with illiquidity explicitly supporting certain waiver scenarios.
source_text:
For Financial Instruments not covered by Rule 3.5.7, waivers may be granted by the Regulator for any of the following:
(a)	orders that are large in scale compared with normal market size;
(b)	orders held in an order management facility of the Recognised Investment Exchange pending disclosure; or
(c)	Financial Instruments for which there is not a liquid market.

question: If an MTF Operator or OTF Operator must follow certain MIR rulebook requirements by reading references to a Recognised Body or Recognised Investment Exchange as references to itself, what does it have to treat “Investment(s)” and “Financial Instrument(s)” as meaning when COBS Chapter 8 is being applied for the stated purposes?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person acting as an MTF Operator or an OTF Operator is required to comply with the listed MIR rulebook requirements that apply to a Recognised Body or Recognised Investment Exchange, but it must apply them by treating references to those entities in the relevant rules as references to the MTF Operator or OTF Operator [#TGT:180edda8-db12-4969-97d5-182435bdf094]. In parallel, for the stated purposes affecting how COBS Chapter 8 is read, the firm must translate key product terms in a specific way: “Investment” and “Investments” must be read as “Spot Commodity” and “Spot Commodities,” and “Financial Instrument” and “Financial Instruments” must be read as “Accepted Spot Commodity” and “Accepted Spot Commodities,” including where those “Financial Instrument(s)” references appear in MIR material that is incorporated through COBS Rule 8.2.1 [#SRC:27f8e3fb-1055-4605-bb11-0b75eba743c2]. So, when the firm is implementing the MIR obligations it must follow, and the relevant COBS Chapter 8 context is engaged for those purposes, it should treat the obligations as applying to spot commodities and accepted spot commodities rather than to investments or financial instruments.
source_text:
For the purposes of Rules 22.7.1 and 22.7.2, the following references in COBS, Chapter 8 should be read as follows:
(a)	references to “Investment” or “Investments” shall be read as references to “Spot Commodity” or “Spot Commodities”, and
(b)	references to “Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments” (including those in MIR as incorporated by virtue of COBS Rule 8.2.1) shall be read as references to “Accepted Spot Commodity” or “Accepted Spot Commodities” as applicable.

question: If there is no written agreement to change what goes into the Governing Contract, how should a Third Party Provider meet the rule that the Customer must get the required information before being bound?
gold_answer: Without a written agreement changing the contract content, the Third Party Provider must do two connected things. The Third Party Provider must provide the Customer with the required information before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]. At the same time, the Governing Contract must contain the specified information unless otherwise agreed in writing [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. That means the contract should set out, among other items, the Third Party Provider’s identity and ADGM contact details, its regulator and Financial Service Permission, the key features and limits of the Third Party Services, what the Customer must provide and how consent works for a Third Party Transaction, timing and maximum service timeframes, all charges and any relevant exchange rate approach, agreed communication methods and information frequency, safeguards and corrective steps (including reporting periods and fraud/security contact procedures), how changes and termination will operate, and available redress (courts/law and any alternative dispute resolution). Delivering these disclosures to the Customer before they are bound, and ensuring they appear in the contract, satisfies both requirements.
source_text:
A Third Party Provider must provide a Customer the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract.
Information provision during period of the Governing Contract

question: When determining the amount of a Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital that may be included in an Authorised Person’s consolidated T1 Capital, how should the Authorised Person apply the 8.0% T1 Capital requirement that is based on Total Risk Exposure Amount, and what components must be summed to calculate that Total Risk Exposure Amount for this purpose?
gold_answer: In determining how much of a Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital can be recognised in the Authorised Person’s consolidated T1 Capital, the Authorised Person must apply a deduction mechanism that depends on an 8.0% T1 Capital requirement calculated by reference to Total Risk Exposure Amount. [#SRC:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14] Specifically, the Authorised Person determines the includable amount by taking the Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital and subtracting an amount equal to (A × B), where A is the lesser of (i) the Subsidiary’s solo 8.0% T1 Capital requirement based on its Total Risk Exposure Amount plus its Combined Buffer Requirement, or (ii) the consolidated T1 Capital relating to the Subsidiary needed on a consolidated basis to meet the Financial Group’s 8.0% T1 Capital requirement based on Total Risk Exposure Amount plus its Combined Buffer Requirement; and B is the Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital as a percentage of all its T1 Capital instruments plus related retained earnings and Share premium accounts. [#SRC:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14] For the Total Risk Exposure Amount used in those 8.0% calculations, the Authorised Person must compute it (after taking into account Rule 3.5.8) as the sum of Credit RWA, and the Risk Exposure Amounts associated with Market Risk, Operational Risk, CVA Risk, and (where applicable) Displaced Commercial Risk (calculated in accordance with IFR Rule 5.4.5). [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]
source_text:
Qualifying T1 Capital instruments included in consolidated T1 Capital. An Authorised Person must determine the amount of qualifying T1 Capital of a Subsidiary that is included in consolidated T1 Capital of the Authorised Person's Financial Group by subtracting from the qualifying T1 Capital of that Subsidiary the result of multiplying the amount referred to in (a) by the percentage referred to in (b):
(a)	the lesser of the following:
(i)	the amount of T1 Capital of that Subsidiary required to meet the sum of the Subsidiary's T1 Capital requirement (on a solo basis) of 8.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, and its Combined Buffer Requirement; or
(ii)	the amount of consolidated T1 Capital that relates to the Subsidiary that is required on a consolidated basis to meet the sum of its Financial Group's T1 Capital requirement of 8.0% of the Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, and its Combined Buffer Requirement;
(b)	the qualifying T1 Capital of the Subsidiary expressed as a percentage of all T1 Capital instruments of that Subsidiary plus the related retained earnings and Share premium accounts.

question: If someone plans to trade a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset, or an Accepted Spot Commodity, when is simply following their own plan not enough to count as insider dealing, and what extra “Inside Information” features would you check for (including for Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives)?
gold_answer: Following a person’s own plan to trade—where they formed the intention to deal before they traded—does not, by itself, amount to contravening section 92(2) (Insider Dealing). [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] To decide whether there is a remaining insider dealing concern, you would then check whether the trade is connected to “Inside Information” as defined for Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities, or Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] Under that definition, the information must be precise and not generally available, it must relate (directly or indirectly) to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers or to the instruments themselves, and it must be the kind of information that would likely have a significant effect on price if it became generally available. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] So the combined approach is: treat “carrying out of own trading intention” as not automatically triggering the insider dealing contravention, [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] but still evaluate whether any relevant non-public, precise, price-significant information about Reporting Entities/Issuers or the instruments is involved, because that is what qualifies as “Inside Information” for these products. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]
source_text: Carrying out of own trading intention. A person will form an intention to deal in a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity before doing so. His carrying out of his own intention will not of itself contravene section 92(2) (Insider Dealing).
target_text:
In relation to Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments which are not Commodity Derivatives, Inside Information is information of a Precise nature which—
(a)	is not generally available;
(b)	relates, directly or indirectly, to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; and
(c)	would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments.

question: When implementing a Corporate Governance framework intended to support prudent and sound long‑term management, to what extent may the Regulator use Rules to impose specific Corporate Governance principles and standards on a Reporting Entity, including obligations for its board of Directors, Controllers, employees, and other persons, and how does this relate to expectations for explaining governance practices to Shareholders?
gold_answer: Across the two provisions, the Regulator is empowered to set enforceable Corporate Governance expectations for a Reporting Entity through Rules, and those expectations are framed as supporting prudent and sound long‑term management in the interests of the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. The SOURCE establishes that the Regulator is entitled to enact rules requiring a Reporting Entity to have a Corporate Governance framework that is adequate to promote prudent and sound management over the long term and aligned with Shareholder interests, and it also indicates that a Reporting Entity’s annual report explanation should aim to show how its actual practices achieve compliance with the intended outcomes and relevant Principles, thereby contributing to prudent and sound management [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1]. The TARGET complements this by specifying that, for the relevant requirement, the Regulator may prescribe by Rules Corporate Governance principles and standards applicable to a Reporting Entity, including requirements applicable to its board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees, or any other person as appropriate, as well as requirements on fair treatment of Shareholders and provisions addressing conflicts of interests [#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d].
source_text: General. Section 73(2) of the FSMR provides that the Regulator is entitled to enact rules requiring a Reporting Entity to have a Corporate Governance framework which is adequate to promote prudent and sound management of the Reporting Entity in the long term interest of the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. Accordingly, in providing its explanation in the annual report as noted in 2, a Reporting Entity should aim to illustrate how its actual practices achieve compliance with the outcomes intended by section 73 of the FSMR and the Principles, and thereby contribute to prudent and sound management of the Reporting Entity.
target_text:
For the purposes of the requirement in subsection ‎(1), the Regulator may by Rules prescribe—
(a)	Corporate Governance principles and standards that apply to a Reporting Entity, including any requirements applicable to its board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees or any other person as appropriate;
(b)	requirements relating to fair treatment of Shareholders; and
(c)	provisions to address conflicts of interests.

question: When a Recognised Clearing House works out how much capital it must hold for the different risks, what is the required source for the latest audited expense information, and how must those operational expenses be handled for accounting?
gold_answer: A Recognised Clearing House must base the operational-expense numbers used in its capital calculations on the most recent audited information from its annual financial statement, and it must consider those operational expenses in line with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) [#SRC:6d70e8b6-10a0-4b13-b3be-912e662e25b0]. This is important because the Recognised Clearing House is required to hold capital that is at least equal to the sum of the capital calculated for the specified risks, and some of those required risk components are explicitly tied to gross operational expenses and annual gross operational expenses [#TGT:fedb7b40-56a0-4cc6-97c6-fef115fc6c1b]. For example, the winding down or restructuring activities component is set by reference to six months’ gross operational expenses, and the business-risk component has a minimum amount expressed as a percentage of annual gross operational expenses (even though the Recognised Clearing House must submit its own estimate for approval) [#TGT:fedb7b40-56a0-4cc6-97c6-fef115fc6c1b]. Using the most recent audited annual financial statement data and applying IFRS treatment ensures those expense-based inputs are derived and handled on the required basis when building up the overall capital sum [#SRC:6d70e8b6-10a0-4b13-b3be-912e662e25b0].
source_text: For the purposes of Rule ‎4.2.1, Recognised Clearing Houses shall use the most recent audited information from their annual financial statement and operational expenses shall be considered in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS).
target_text:
A Recognised Clearing House shall hold capital more than or equal to the sum of capital calculated in respect of the following risks.
(a)	Winding down or restructuring activities. Six months' gross operational expenses.
(b)	Operational risks. A Recognised Clearing House shall calculate its capital requirement for operational risks using either the Basic Indicator Approach or, with prior authorisation from the Regulator, the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach, both as provided specifically in Appendix 7.3 and generally in Appendix 7 of PRU.
(c)	Credit, counterparty credit and market risks. A Recognised Clearing House shall calculate its capital requirements as the sum of 10% of its risk-weighted exposure amounts for credit and counterparty credit risk and its capital requirements for market risk calculated in accordance with Appendix 6 of PRU, subject to the following.
(i)	For the calculation of the risk-weighted exposure amounts for credit risk and counterparty credit risk, a Recognised Clearing House shall apply the Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM) method in section 4.8 of PRU.
(ii)	Where a Recognised Clearing House does not use its own resources, the Recognised Clearing House shall apply a risk weight of 250% to its exposure stemming from any contributions to the default fund of another Clearing house and a risk weight of 2% to any trade exposures with another Clearing house.
(d)	Business risk. A Recognised Clearing House shall submit to the Regulator for approval its own estimate of the capital necessary to cover losses resulting from business risk based on reasonably foreseeable adverse scenarios relevant to its business model. The capital requirement for business risk shall be equal to the approved estimate and shall be subject to a minimum amount of 25% of its annual gross operational expenses.

question: If an Authorised Person wants to count financial collateral, what are the two allowed methods it can use, and if it picks the FCCA method, what kinds of collateral count (including the extra rules for fund Units)?
gold_answer: To recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, an Authorised Person is required to use one of two methods: the Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) or the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA). [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19] Choosing FCCA matters because it determines what can be treated as eligible financial Collateral under that approach. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] Under FCCA, eligible financial Collateral includes any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5, plus any equity Security (and this explicitly includes a convertible bond) as long as it is traded on a regulated exchange. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] FCCA also allows Units in a Collective Investment Fund, but only where the Fund invests in the regulated-exchange-traded equity Securities described above and two conditions are satisfied: the Unit price is publicly quoted daily, and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property is invested in instruments listed in the FCCA rule and in Rule 4.13.5. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] This FCCA eligibility list sits alongside the overarching requirement that the Authorised Person must use either FCSA (adopting the treatment under Rule 4.13.5 for collateral composition) or FCCA (adopting the treatment under Rule 4.13.6) when recognising eligible financial Collateral. [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19]
source_text:
An Authorised Person must use either the:
(a)	Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.5 in relation to the composition of financial Collateral; or
(b)	Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA) which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.6;
to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.
target_text:
For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises:
(a)	any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5;
(b)	any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and
(c)	any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where:
(i)	a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and
(ii)	at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: If the Third Party Provider confirms a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, and it causes an unauthorised Payment Transaction, who must be refunded and how quickly must the Third Party Provider make the refund?
gold_answer: Once the Third Party Provider has confirmed that a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide a refund as soon as practicable and no later than the end of the next day after the day it made that confirmation [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]. If the situation also meets the additional conditions that an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with the relevant authorisation requirement and that it leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, then the Third Party Provider must make refunds to two recipients, subject to the stated rules: it must refund the Primary Financial Institution for any amount the Primary Financial Institution may already have refunded to the Customer, and it must refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, minus any amount the Third Party Provider has refunded to the Primary Financial Institution [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe]. In practice, this means the Third Party Provider must act quickly after confirmation, and it must ensure the Customer is made whole while avoiding paying the same amount twice when the Primary Financial Institution has already reimbursed the Customer.
source_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. The Third Party Provider must provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 as soon as practicable, and in any event no later than the end of the day following the day on which it has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed.
target_text:
Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. Subject to Rules 20.10 and 20.11, where an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with Rule 20.7 and the Third Party Transaction leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider must:
(a)	refund the Primary Financial Institution for the amount that the Primary Financial Institution may have already refunded to the Customer; and
(b)	refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, less any amount that the Third Party Provider has refunded to the Primary Financial Institution.

question: If a Third Party Provider is about to sign a Governing Contract with a Customer, what details have to be in the contract (unless they both agree something else in writing), and when does the Customer need to get that information so they are not bound too early?
gold_answer: The Customer must be given the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract. [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8] Unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer agree otherwise in writing, the Governing Contract must itself contain that information, so providing the contract with the required content is the normal way to meet the pre-binding delivery requirement. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] The required contract content includes: who the Third Party Provider is (its name, its ADGM office address/contact details, and its Regulator and Financial Service Permission details); what the Third Party Services are (main characteristics, what customer information/unique identifier is needed for a Third Party Transaction, how consent is given, when a Third Party Transaction is treated as received, maximum service time, and any usage limits); and what it costs (all charges and, where relevant, exchange rate details including Reference Exchange Rates and how changes apply if agreed). [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] It also must explain communications (including technical requirements and what Customer information is transferred to the Customer’s Financial Institution), safeguards and corrective measures (including how/when to notify unauthorised or incorrect Third Party Transactions and liability/refund conditions), how changes and termination work, and redress options. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Even though information can be provided during the period of the Governing Contract, the key timing point is that the Customer must receive it before being bound. [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]
source_text:
A Third Party Provider must provide a Customer the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract.
Information provision during period of the Governing Contract

question: When assessing whether it may give a direction requiring a Recognised Body to take specified steps (including granting premises access for inspection or suspending an activity), in what circumstances will the Regulator usually consider revoking the Recognition Order instead of proceeding with that direction?
gold_answer: The Regulator may direct a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements, including granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body’s premises to inspect premises or documents and requiring suspension of the carrying on of an activity for a specified period [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500]. However, the Regulator will usually consider revoking a Recognition Order rather than relying on such a direction where the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to satisfy one or more Recognition Requirements and the failure has or will have serious consequences, or where it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction. Revocation will also usually be considered where, for some other reason, it would not be appropriate for the Regulator to give a direction under its power to give directions, and where the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the relevant 12-month period after the Recognition Order took effect or at any time during the six months ending with the day the Recognition Order is revoked [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a].
target_text: The Regulator has the power to give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps in order to secure its compliance with the Recognition Requirements. Those steps may include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body's premises for the purposes of inspecting those premises or any documents on the premises and the suspension of the carrying on of any activity by the Recognised Body for the period specified in the direction.

question: When trading activity might be seen as creating an artificial price, what does the Regulator look at, and how does that connect to the definition of Behaviour that uses transactions or orders to trade to create a false impression or keep prices at an abnormal or artificial level?
gold_answer: The definition focuses on Behaviour where a person effects transactions or orders to trade without legitimate reasons and not in line with Accepted Market Practices, and the activity either gives (or is likely to give) a false or misleading impression about supply, demand or price, or secures the price at an abnormal or artificial level for one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]. When the Regulator considers whether conduct creates, or is likely to create, an artificial price, it is likely to take into account practical indicators that show whether the trading could be driving an artificial outcome [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1]. These indicators include: (1) how much the person had a direct or indirect interest in the price or value of the relevant instrument or asset; (2) whether price, rate or option-volatility movements (and the volatility of those factors) are outside normal intra-day, daily, weekly or monthly ranges; and (3) whether the person repeatedly and consistently moved their bid, Offer, or the price paid up or down over time. The Regulator uses these factors to connect observed trading patterns to the risk of a false impression or an abnormal/artificial price level.
source_text:
Factors relating to creating an artificial price. In considering whether or not conduct creates, or is likely to create, an artificial price under section 92(4)(b), the Regulator is likely to take into account factors such as:
(a)	the extent to which the person had a direct or indirect interest in the price or value of the Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity;
(b)	the extent to which price, rate or option volatility movements, and the volatility of these factors for the Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity in question, are outside their normal intra-day, daily, weekly or monthly range; or
(c)	whether a person has successively and consistently increased or decreased his bid, Offer or the price he has paid for a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity.
target_text:
The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which—
(a)	give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or
(b)	secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: If the Investigator needs information or documents during an investigation, what are the two ways they can get them, and what kinds of things can a written notice force someone (including someone not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to do?
gold_answer: The passages describe two ways the Investigator may obtain relevant information and/or documents during an investigation: on a compulsory basis (mainly by using its powers under section 206(1)(b) and (c) of FSMR) or on a voluntary basis. [#SRC:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4] When using the compulsory approach, the Investigator may send a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, even if that person is not connected to the Person Under Investigation. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] That notice can require several concrete actions that help the Investigator obtain information and documents, including: attending an interview at a specified time and place and answering questions; producing specified documents (or documents of a specified description) at a specified time and place; and providing information or assistance the Investigator requires. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The notice can also require the person to allow the Investigator to enter the person’s business premises during normal business hours so the Investigator can inspect and copy documents on those premises. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] If the Investigator proceeds voluntarily instead, the text indicates the Investigator may obtain the relevant information and/or documents without relying on the compulsory powers. [#SRC:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4]
source_text: Power to require documents or information . During an investigation, the Investigator may obtain relevant information and/or documents either on a compulsory basis, principally through the exercise of its powers under section 206(1)(b) and (c) of FSMR, or on a voluntary basis.

question: In a Framework Contract, when the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, how may the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider contractually handle (i) charges for information requested by the Payment Service User and (ii) the applicability of the specific rule on “charges for information,” and what form must that agreement take?
gold_answer: The Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User can contractually set charges for certain user-requested information, but they can also (if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person) agree to disapply the specific “charges for information” rules, provided the agreement is in writing. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] In particular, the parties may agree on charges for information supplied at the Payment Service User’s request when that information goes beyond what Section 19.2 requires, is delivered more often than Section 19.2 specifies, or is sent using a communication method different from what the Framework Contract specifies. [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7] Separately, where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may agree in writing that Rules 19.2.16 and 19.2.17 (identified as covering charges for information) do not apply. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] Read together, this means the parties can (a) price qualifying “additional/more frequent/alternative channel” information requests, and (b) if eligible, document in writing that the referenced “charges for information” rules are switched off for their relationship. [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7] [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]
target_text:
The Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User may agree on charges for any information which is provided at the request of the Payment Service User where such information is:
(a)	additional to the information required to be provided or made available by Section 19.2;
(b)	provided more frequently than is specified in Section 19.2; or
(c)	transmitted by means of communication other than those specified in the Framework Contract.

question: When a Fund Manager appoints an auditor to audit a Fund’s financial statements under IAASB standards, what specific statements must the Fund Manager ensure the Auditor includes in the resulting Fund Auditor’s Report, including any points that apply at Fund or Sub-Fund level for the annual accounting period?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager must both (i) formally instruct its auditor in writing to perform the audit under the relevant IAASB standards and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report, and (ii) when procuring that report, ensure the Auditor’s report contains the required set of statements about the financial statements and related matters. [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579] Specifically, the Fund Manager must ensure the Auditor states whether the financial statements were properly prepared using the financial reporting standards the Fund has adopted under FUNDS, and whether they present a true and fair view of the Fund’s financial position. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] That true-and-fair assessment must cover net income and net gains or losses of the Fund Property (or, where relevant, the Fund Property attributable to the Sub-Fund) for the annual accounting period, and the financial position of the Fund or Sub-Fund at the end of that period. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] The report must also address whether proper accounting records have not been kept or whether the statements fail to agree with records/returns or fail to comply with applicable reporting standards, confirm whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations, and state whether the Directors’ report or Fund Manager’s report is consistent with the financial statements, plus any other matter required by FUNDS. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]

Function of the Auditor. A Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to:
(a)	conduct an audit of the Fund's financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB); and
(b)	produce a Fund Auditor's Report on the audited financial statements in accordance with GEN Rule 6.6.8.

question: If the Investigator asks for “information” in a written notice, does that mean only documents, or can it include answers and computer data too? How does this fit with the Investigator’s ability to require interviews and questions?
gold_answer: A written notice can require more than just documents. The Investigator may require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to provide such information as the Investigator may require, and may also require the person to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. The Investigator’s power to require a person to give, or procure the giving of, information is intended to be broad [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. “Information” can include knowledge about a matter, fact, or circumstance, and knowledge gained through work or study. It also includes data obtained as output from a computer through processing, and any data at any stage of processing, including input, output, storage, or transmission data [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. Beyond data, it can include an explanation or statement, identification details, and a response to a question. That means the Investigator’s interview-and-questions power and the information-request power work together: the “information” requested can be provided as answers, explanations, identifications, or relevant computer data, not only as produced documents [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32].

question: If an Authorised Person is working out CET1 deductions for Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), what position basis should they use (gross long vs net long) for Trading Book holdings, and how do they handle Trading Book holdings that are index Securities?
gold_answer: For Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), the Trading Book calculation uses a net long position approach in the same underlying Exposure when the maturity condition for the short position is met, and this sits alongside the general concept that deductible holdings are calculated using gross long positions for Rule 3.10.7(f), (g) and (h) (noting the stated cross-reference to Rule 3.10.15). [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c] [#SRC:40c66431-d7b0-41ae-bc47-0ae63f4d9454] Specifically, for holdings in the Trading Book of capital instruments of Relevant Entities, the holdings must be calculated on the basis of the net long position in the same underlying Exposure, provided the short position either matches the long position’s maturity or has a residual maturity of at least one year. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c] If the Trading Book exposure is indirect and takes the form of holdings of index Securities, the amount to be deducted must be determined by calculating the underlying Exposure to the capital instruments of the Relevant Entities in the indices. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c] This answers both how to treat direct Trading Book holdings (net long with a maturity test) and how to treat index-based indirect holdings (look-through to underlying Exposure) within the broader gross-long deduction framing. [#SRC:40c66431-d7b0-41ae-bc47-0ae63f4d9454]
source_text: CET1 Deductions - investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(f), (g) and (h), the amount of holdings of CET1 Capital instruments and other capital instruments of Relevant Entities to be deducted, must be calculated, subject to Rule 3.10.15, on the basis of the gross long positions.
target_text:
CET1 Deductions - investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), an Authorised Person must make the deductions in accordance with the following:
(a)	the holdings in the Trading Book of the capital instruments of Relevant Entities must be calculated on the basis of the net long position in the same underlying Exposure provided the maturity of the short position matches the maturity of the long position or has a residual maturity of at least one year; and
(b)	the amount to be deducted for indirect holdings in the Trading Book of the capital instruments of Relevant Entities that take the form of holdings of index Securities must be determined by calculating the underlying Exposure to the capital instruments of the Relevant Entities in the indices.
